With the recession eating into profits, many employers face a difficult choice: cut jobs or cut wages.
More often than not, companies choose to cut jobs.
That's because many fear that if they do slash pay, the best employees will leave and the least productive ones will stick around.
But Federal Express decided to take that risk.
Late last year FedEx cut management and professional salaries by five percent.
Some benefits have also been cut.
This has saved jobs.
But according to FedEx aircraft mechanic Billy Selph, morale has still taken a hit.
When I first started 13 years ago, FedEx had a philosophy they called PSP — people, service, profit — whereby you took care of the people, provided good service, the profit would come.
And as of late they've given up on the people portion.
It's - the morale is pretty bad there now.
How do you know that?
How does it express itself?
We no longer feel that it's, you know, our company.
At one time — or especially when I hired on — everybody felt a part of FedEx, and that feeling's just no longer there.
